Hi,

thanks for your reply! Hadn't noticed about the socket stuff
and the CDX functionality.

> >We would like to see at some point of time a package that combines
> >the best features of both the DK and the IA package. Ideally this 
> >package should:
> >  - Be a small, closed enitity.
> >  - Be able to mimic the most important Alexa tools.
> >  - Support both .arc and .arc.gz.
> >  - Provide efficient and convenient access to a single object
> >    given a file and an offset.
> >  - Provide efficient and convenient traversal of archives.
> >  - Provide convenient writing of ARC (and .arc.gz) files.
> >    (Large-scale efficient writing may be left out - this is more 
of
> >     a harvester issue).

> All of the above sounds good.  Would be good to break the reading 
and 
> writing of ARCs out of the crawler and have it instead include a 
jar.

I agree. I managed to sepearate out a subset of the code that 
was "not much
larger" than the parts of archive.org.io.arc that I needed, but it 
wasn't
easy (when you're new to the code, like I was).

> >public class ShareableARCRecord{
> >    public ShareableARCRecord(ARCRecord record,File file);
> >    public File getFile();
> >    public ARCRecordMetaData getMetaData();
> >    public byte[] readAll() throws IOException;
> >    public InputStream getObjectAsInputStream() throws IOException;
> >}

> >The File is just the name of the file in which the record
> >was found.
> >This is useful for indexing information.
> >As the class name indicates, the two latter methods may be called
> >any number of times without "interference".

> Should we add the arc file name to ARCRecord metadata?

I think that would be really good. My above code is a hack
that superficially adds the information. :-|

>(Not full-path,  just the name)?

I would prefer it as a java.io.File? This is the infomation supplied
to the ARCReaderFactory, and the absolute path can be retrieved from
it if needed (as it might be when building an index).

Thanks again,
Niels
